column1: 2024-09-17T22:52:36Z,8530,,LS AI TP VJ,,newgraph_lschick,8530,newgraph_airvine,,,,45,Sandstone Creek ,McDonnell FSR,,MoF,Closed Bottom Structure,Round Culvert,,2.4,38,"The stream has good quality habitat with abundant overhanging vegetation and boulders providing cover, pools for overwintering fish, and gravel suitable for spawning. Rainbow trout, cutthroat trout, and Dolly Varden were captured during sampling. Very large culvert with a significant amount of road fill (9m).    There was an engineering site survey conducted in 2024 but the design plans were put on hold due to high replacement costs and uncertainty around if salmon could access the crossing due to potential barriers downstream. DFO was involved and reported that coho were spawning downstream of the crossing in October 2024.",,2024-09-17T22:52:36Z,9,582719,6073883,No,,,No,,9,0.5,0.4,No,5,3.9,2,No,Yes,Deep Fill,High,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_lschick,No,Yes,No,high,1,1,1,3,"The culvert is in good shape, with no blockage issues. There is some erosion under the pipe outlet. ",1,1,1,4,"Due to the large culvert and substantial amount of road fill, flooding would likely not impact the road infrastructure.",1,1,3,2,10,5,22,26,"Although the low-traffic FSR allows for easier access, the substantial road fill would make construction costly and challenging. Given the fish-bearing stream and high-quality habitat, replacement is a high priority, with significant potential environmental impact.",ignore_mobile/photos/20240917_155416.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240917_161114.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240917_155939.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240917_161116.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240917_155933.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240917_155937.jpg,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240917_161857.jpg,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column1: 2024-09-18T21:53:45Z,198935,,LS,,newgraph_lschick,198935,newgraph_lschick,,,,358,Tributary to Knapper Creek ,Gold Creek FSR,,Canfor R07549 6,Closed Bottom Structure,Round Culvert,,1.2,20,"The culvert is deteriorating at the inlet. Large outlet pool where fish were captured during sampling. The stream flows from the outlet pool along the left-hand side into a well-defined channel with gravels suitable for spawning and several pools, providing good habitat. A moderate amount of road fill is present.",,2024-09-18T21:53:45Z,9,636440,6020756,No,,,No,,4,0.15,0.8,No,1.5,2.7,2.2,Yes,Yes,Deep Fill,Medium,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_lschick,No,No,Yes,high,1,1,1,3,"The culvert is deteriorating at the inlet. No erosion issues.
,2,1,2,5,Although the culvert is large, the presence of a significant outlet pool suggests it may be undersized for the stream and might not effectively handle flood events.",1,1,6,5,10,5,28,33,"

The substantial amount of road fill would make construction expensive and challenging. As a fish-bearing stream flowing into Knapper Creek, potential environmental impacts could be significant.",ignore_mobile/photos/20240918_145449.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240918_145453.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240918_150507.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240918_145456.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240918_145451.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240918_150354.jpg,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240918_151215.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240918_150403.jpg,,,Channel from outlet ,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column9:
>Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment

",,,,No,TRUE,"The culvert is deteriorating at the inlet. Large outlet pool where fish were captured during sampling. The stream flows from the outlet pool along the left-hand side into a well-defined channel with gravels suitable for spawning and several pools, providing good habitat. A moderate amount of road fill is present.",TRUE

column1: 2024-09-18T21:33:31Z,198940,,AI,,newgraph_airvine,198940,newgraph_airvine,,,,49,Tributary to Knapper Creek ,HM7504,0.3,Canfor R07549 16,Closed Bottom Structure,Round Culvert,,0.95,25,"Very nice stream with good flow, abundant gravels for spawning, and undercut banks and occasional deep pools for rearing. Confirmed populations of cutthroat trout, rainbow trout, and Dolly Varden. The culvert is significantly undersized for the stream, and the road appears to be failing, likely due to a partially clogged inlet and spring freshet. Habitat confirmations were completed for this crossing and the next upstream crossing (198935) on the Gold FSR.",,2024-09-18T21:33:31Z,9,636706,6020960,No,,,Yes,30,1.75,0,0.9,Yes,2,4.3,3,Yes,Yes,Deep Fill,Medium,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_airvine,No,No,Yes,high,,,,,"Road column appears to be failing, likely due to a partially clogged inlet and spring freshet. column1: 2024-09-19T19:18:58Z,195943,,LS ,,newgraph_lschick,195943,newgraph_lschick,1755230,,,363,Stock Creek ,Barrett Station Road,,MoTi ,Closed Bottom Structure,Oval Culvert,,2.2,14,"The culvert has a substantial outlet drop of 1.05 m, with signs of high flows at the outlet. The stream likely contains numerous pools during higher flows but had very low flows at the time of assessment. Flowing through agricultural land on both sides, the stream is heavily eroded downstream, making it a strong candidate for fencing and riparian management.  Upstream habitat was less eroded and consisted of mature riparian vegetation providing good habitat for fish. Only two fish were captured during sampling (both in the deep outlet pool), which was unexpected given the good habitat. Conductivity was extremely high, possibly due to upstream cattle activity and surrounding land use.       ",,2024-09-19T19:18:58Z,9,645439,6035050,No,,,No,,0.4,1.05,0.6,No,1.5,2.6,2,No,Yes,Deep Fill,Medium,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_lschick,No,Yes,,mod,1,2,1,4,Embankment fill erosion was observed on the outlet side of the road near the culvert.,1,3,3,7,"The culvert is large, and signs of high flows at the outlet suggest the stream already accommodates substantial water volumes. While a flood would likely not impact the culvert, it could affect downstream agricultural fields.",5,2,8,7,10,5,37,44,"The road provides access to several houses and had consistent local traffic during the assessment. Although there is minimal road fill, the paved surface would make construction more difficult. Fish were captured during sampling.",ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_122912.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_122917.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_122925.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_122920.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_122914.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_122923.jpg,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_124131.jpg,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column9: color:#0984ff
column10:
>Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment

",,,,No,TRUE,"Extremely big outlet drop, and outlet of culvert shows signs of high flows. Really nice dream which likely has lots of pools at higher flows, but very low flows at time of assessment. Stream flows through agricultural land on both sides and is very very eroded downstream, would be a great place for fencing and reparian management. only two fish caught during sampling, which was surprisingly given the nice habitat. Conductivity was extremely high, perhaps due to cattle upstream and in the area. ",TRUE

column1: 2024-09-19T20:03:29Z,195934,,LS VJ,,newgraph_lschick,195934,newgraph_lschick,1755233,,,364,Dunalter Creek ,Barret Station Road,,MoTi ,Closed Bottom Structure,Round Culvert,,1.2,16,"The inlet of the culvert is approximately 3 m downstream of the outlet of culvert 195935, which crosses under the Houston Airport Rd. The stream has an estimated slope of 1%. Downstream of the culvert, the stream is heavily overgrown. The culvert has holes in the bottom about 2 m from the outlet and is backwatered up to that point.",,2024-09-19T20:03:29Z,9,645128,6034597,No,,,Yes,15,2,0,0.15,No,4,1.6,1,No,No,Deep Fill,Medium,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_lschick,No,Yes,,low,1,1,1,3,There is some blockage present in the middle of the pipe.,1,1,1,4,,1,7,9,9,7,5,38,42,"Fish species documented in FISS upstream in Barrett Lake include CT, KO, LSU, and RB.",ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_131452.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_131720.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_131500.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_131722.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_131454.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_131458.jpg,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_140000.jpg,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column9: color:#0984ff
column10:
>Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment

",,,,No,,Inlet of culvert is roughly 3m downstream of the outlet of culvert 195935 which goes under the upper road. Stream slope estimated at 1%. Stream is super overgrown downstream of culvert. Culvert has holes in the bottom roughly 2 m from the outlet and is back watered to that point ,TRUE

column1: 2024-09-19T20:34:36Z,195935,,LS VJ,,newgraph_lschick,195935,newgraph_lschick,2078335,,,365,Dunalter Creek ,Houston Airport Road,,MoTi ,Closed Bottom Structure,Round Culvert,,1.2,38,"Upstream of the crossing, there is good habitat for fish, including undercut banks, functional large woody debris, healthy riparian vegetation, and several pools suitable for overwintering fish. A fish ~100 mm in length was observed in one of the pools upstream. A barbed wire fence is present when accessing the inlet. The culvert is extremely long (38 m), with its outlet located approximately 3 m upstream of the inlet of crossing 195934. Downstream of crossing 195934 the stream is heavily overgrown.",,2024-09-19T20:34:36Z,9,645104,6034615,No,,,No,,11,0.2,0.15,No,1,1.7,2,No,Yes,Deep Fill,Medium,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_lschick,No,Yes,,mod,1,1,1,3,Some debris is present inside the culvert.,1,1,1,4,"

Approximately 10 m of road fill is present above the culvert, making flood impacts on Houston Airport Road unlikely. However, a flood could potentially wash out Barrett Station Road, which is located directly below the outlet.",1,3,2,1,10,5,22,26,Fish were observed in the stream during the assessment. The substantial amount of road fill would make construction challenging and costly.,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_134429.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_134441.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_135656.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_134443.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_134800.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_135654.jpg,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_135937.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_134450.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240919_134500.jpg,,Pools,Pools,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

",,,,No,,"Nice stream with several pools suitable for overwintering fish, 100 mm fish observed in one of the pools. There is a Barbwire fence when walking down to the inlet",TRUE

column1: 2024-09-20T20:15:50Z,203122,1805555,AI,,newgraph_airvine,1805555,newgraph_airvine,,,,54,Simpson Creek,Railway,,CN Rail,Closed Bottom Structure,Round Culvert,,3,25,"Although this culvert is on Simpson Creek, it is not currently conveying the main flow and remains mostly dry. Two 1.5 m diameter pipes run under the railway, approximately 30 m apart. The southern pipe is fully embedded with an average embedment depth of 25 cm, while the northern pipe is currently passing all stream flow. This is a high-value stream with extensive gravel areas suitable for steelhead, coho, and chinook salmon spawning upstream. The adjacent landowner has reported recent observations of steelhead spawning and has historical knowledge of chinook spawning approximately 300 m downstream from Nielsen Road.",,2024-09-20T20:15:50Z,9,614941,6075232,No,20,Yes,No,,1,0.05,0.9,Yes,2,5,1,Yes,Yes,Deep Fill,High,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_airvine,Yes,No,,low,1,1,1,3,"
The pipes are quite rusty, but overall the crossing is in good condition.",1,2,2,5,"The combined 3 m diameter of the two pipes is undersized for the stream
column2: however, the low gradient makes a washout of the railway unlikely.",,1,2,1,10,1,,,A railway crossing so it is primarily related to goods transportation rather than community access. Remediating a railway crossing is reportedly extremely expensive and challenging. The stream is confirmed to support salmon and steelhead populations.,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_134645.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_134012.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_134641.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_134017.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_134009.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_134638.jpg,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_140931.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_141001.jpg,,Outlet2,Barrel2,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column9: color:#007aff
column10:
>Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment

",,,,No,," Although this culvert is on Simpson Creek, it does not currently pass the main flow. Discovered is primarily dry at this time. It’s fully embedded. there are 21.5 m pipes under the railway. Farther north pipe currently is passing all the water. Southern pipe is fully embedded and average of 25 cm. High value stream with extensive areas of gravel, suitable for steelhead and coal, and Chinook spawning upstream. Adjacent landowner reports observed recent spawning of steelhead and historic knowledge of Chinook spawning at location approximately 300 m downstream from Nielsen Road. ",TRUE

column1: Three 0.95 m pipes run under a private driveway. The pipe lengths and gradients are estimated, with two pipes appearing fully embedded and one slightly elevated by approximately 30 cm. The stream is channelized with large boulders throughout the property. Beaver activity is evident, with debris at the inlet and three dams ranging from 0.4 to 1 m high within 150 m upstream. The landowner reported previous blockages caused by beavers, requiring the inlet to be cleared and significant amounts of accumulated material to be dredged out.",,2024-09-20T22:17:35Z,9,615326,6075142,Yes,0.2,Yes,No,,1,0,0.3,Yes,3,7,1.5,Yes,Yes,Deep Fill,High,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_airvine,Yes,No,,low,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_152118.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_152147.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_152129.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_152113.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_152137.jpg,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_152159.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_152208.jpg,,Inlet2,Inlet3,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column9:
>Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment

",,,,No,,30.95 m pipes under private driveway. Length of pipe and gradients estimated two of the pipes are appear to be fully embedded with one slightly elevated from the others approximately 30 cm. Stream is channelized with large boulders throughout this entire property. Material from beavers in the inlet and three dimes ranging from .4 to 1 m high within 150 m upstream. Landowner reports that the crossing has been cleaned out before after it was blocked by beavers with dredging extensive Amos material out from the inlet ,TRUE

column1: 2024-09-20T22:29:13Z,58245,,AI,,newgraph_airvine,58245,newgraph_airvine,1514706,1514705,,60,Simpson Creek,Lake Kathlyn Road,,MoTi ,Closed Bottom Structure,Round Culvert,,2.5,20,"Two 1.25 m pipes are present and are heavily corroded. Upstream and downstream, the streambanks are heavily modified adjacent to private land, including riparian vegetation removal, stream channelization, and bank armouring. High-value steelhead, coho, and chinook spawning habitat is documented further upstream above the railway crossing.",,2024-09-20T22:29:13Z,9,615383,6075125,No,,,No,,2.2,0,0.3,No,2,7,1.5,Yes,Yes,Deep Fill,High,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_airvine,No,No,Yes,low,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_153718.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_153725.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_153737.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_153729.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_153722.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_153732.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_153805.jpg,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240920_153809.jpg,,,Condition pipe2 corroded ,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column1: 2024-09-24T20:32:14Z,198217,,LS AI,,newgraph_airvine,198217,newgraph_airvine,,,,72,Sik-e-dakh ,Sik-e-dakh Water Tower Road,,MoTi ,Open Bottom Structure,Bridge,,14,4.5,"The culvert was replaced with a bridge, featuring excellent construction with a wide channel beneath the structure. Riprap has been covered with soil to promote vegetation growth, and significant riparian restoration is underway with trees and shrubs being planted. Overall, this is a well-executed replacement project.",,2024-09-24T20:32:14Z,9,582850,6130490,No,,,No,,,0,0,No,0,0,0,No,No,,,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_airvine,No,Yes,,low,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240924_134025.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240924_134253.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240924_134310.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240924_134257.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240924_134247.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240924_134303.jpg,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240924_134537.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240924_134318.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240924_134325.jpg,,Cuttings ,Samplings ,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column9:
>Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment

",,,,No,,Culvert replaced with Bridge. Really nice construction job with wide Channell beneath the bridge. Riprap covered in dirt to allow for growth. Lots of reparian work taking place with trees and shrubs being planted. A really good replacement job. ,TRUE

column1: 2024-09-26T00:43:25Z,198916,,LS JD,,newgraph_lschick,198916,newgraph_lschick,,,,377,Comeau Creek ,Railway ,,CN Rail,Closed Bottom Structure,Concrete Box,,1.5,100,"The concrete box culvert is approximately 100 m long beneath a railway crossing, with about 30–40 m of fill above it. A swift current flows through the culvert, and installing baffles could improve fish passage. Fish sampling captured cutthroat trout and Dolly Varden. There is a moderate outlet drop, but adult fish could likely move upstream. The habitat upstream features good flow through a steeper section with a healthy, mature mixed riparian forest, stable banks, and gravel pockets suitable for spawning coho, Dolly Varden, and cutthroat trout. Downstream, abundant boulders create step pools alongside frequent large woody debris, though high flows limited suitable fish habitat during the survey. Although construction would be expensive and challenging, this site is a high priority for restoration follow-up. BC Freshwater atlas mapping of this watershed is incorrect as the main stream at the confluence with the Skeena River is actually Comeau Creek vs Gershwin Creek. Therefore, this crossing is actually on Comeau Creek. ",,2024-09-26T00:43:25Z,9,580463,6115769,No,,,No,,30,0.45,0.35,No,6,4.4,4.4,No,No,Deep Fill,Medium,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_lschick,No,No,Yes,high,1,1,1,3,The concrete box culvert is located under 30 m of road fill. A log is positioned across the inlet but does not obstruct fish passage. No erosion or embankment issues were observed.,1,2,2,5,"This is a railway crossing with 30 m of road fill, making it very unlikely that a flood would damage the railway.",5,7,10,1,5,5,33,38,Fish sampling confirmed this is a fish-bearing stream. Construction would be extremely expensive and challenging due to the railway crossing and the substantial amount of fill.,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_111534.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_111541.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_111554.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_111549.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_111536.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_111552.jpg,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_112241.jpg,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column9: color:#0984ff
column10:
>Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment

",,,,No,TRUE,"Concrete box culvert, roughly 100 m long under a railway crossing. Roughly 30 to 40 m of Phil. Very swift current running through The concrete box. Baffles could be very helpful. Decent outlet drop but adults could get upstream. Nice habitat, upstream and downstream, See habitat confirmations for more information. Construction would be expensive and difficult but a high priority for restoration follow up. ",TRUE

column1: 2024-09-26T05:27:12Z,203125,2024092550,LS JD ,,newgraph_lschick,2024092550,newgraph_lschick,,,,380,Comeau Creek ,Private property ,,Private,Closed Bottom Structure,Round Culvert,,1.37,6,"The landowner has constructed a bridge over the stream with two culverts, measuring 0.47 m and 0.9 m in diameter. Some flow passes through the culverts while some bypasses them, though it is unclear if fish can navigate the bypassing flow. The bridge appears to provide access to adjacent agricultural fields. High-quality habitat with numerous pools and abundant gravel is present, but strong currents in the culverts due to significant flow likely inhibit fish passage.BC Freshwater atlas mapping of this watershed is incorrect as the main stream at the confluence with the Skeena River is actually Comeau Creek vs Gershwin Creek. Therefore, this crossing is actually on Comeau Creek. ",,2024-09-26T05:27:12Z,9,581313,6115473,No,,,No,,0.5,0,0.3,Yes,2,6,5,No,No,Deep Fill,High,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_lschick,Yes,No,,mod,1,1,1,3,"

The landowner constructed a bridge with two culverts underneath, though the structure appears poorly built.",4,5,20,23,Culverts would likely wash out at high flows.  ,1,1,10,10,5,5,32,55,"Landowner made this bridge with two culverts underneath, would be really easy to disassemble          ",ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_153229.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_154821.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_154844.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_154837.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_153237.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_154840.jpg,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_154943.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_154853.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_155016.jpg,,Two pipe ,Passage ,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column9:
>Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment

",,,,No,FALSE,"Landowner has made a bridge over the stream with two culverts, one at 0.47 diameter one at 0.9 diameter. The bigger pipe is made of two pipes combined of different diameters, but they are pretty much the same. Bridge seems to connect his to agricultural fields. stream still flows to the left of the culverts but unclear if it’s possible to fish. Really nice dream with quality habitat, lots of pools and gravel present. Stream has a significant amount of flow which is creating a lot of current in the culverts, which would definitely inhibit fish.",FALSE

column1: Steel structure suitable for foot traffic or ATV use, located on private land. vs Gershwin Creek. This crossing is actually on Gershwin Creek, which is a tributary to Comeau Creek. column1: There is a deep outlet pool, suggesting the culvert is undersized for the stream. High-quality gravels were present at the pool’s outlet, and upstream of the crossing, there was high-value habitat with frequent overwintering pools, spawning gravels, and adequate riparian cover with large cottonwoods throughout. This site was part of a habitat confirmation assessment, with the stream surveyed from the downstream railway crossing up to this location and an additional 600 m upstream. Downstream, crossing 198916 consists of a large, long box culvert beneath the railway with minimal flow depth and a swift current, making it unlikely that fish from the mainstem of the Skeena River can access this site until the railway barrier is addressed. Fish sampling at this site captured cutthroat trout and Dolly Varden.BC Freshwater atlas mapping of this watershed is incorrect as the main stream at the confluence with the Skeena River is actually Comeau Creek vs Gershwin Creek. Therefore, this crossing is actually on Comeau Creek. ",,2024-09-26T03:57:54Z,9,581250,6115660,No,,,No,,2.5,0.35,0.85,No,3,5,3,No,No,Deep Fill,Medium,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_airvine,No,No,Yes,mod,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_143418.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_143444.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_140641.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_143446.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_140628.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20240925_140637.jpg,,,,,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

",,,,No,TRUE,"Deep outlet pool indicates culvert is undersized nice gravel on outlet pool outlet. column1: This is a newer PVC pipe with a beaver grate on the inlet. Debris clogging about 20 cm of the inlet has caused water to back up upstream of the crossing. Downstream, the drainage is very small, with a fence located approximately 10 m away. BC Freshwater atlas mapping of this watershed is incorrect as the main stream at the confluence with the Skeena River is actually Comeau Creek vs Gershwin Creek. This crossing is actually on Gershwin Creek, which is a tributary to Comeau Creek. column1: This is a brand-new replacement structure, extremely well built with extensive embedment that includes numerous large boulders, cobbles, and gravel. The multiplate round structure is embedded nearly 2 m. Upstream, woody debris and boulder structures are cabled together for added stability. This massive construction project involved a substantial amount of fill extending 60 m downstream and over 200 m upstream. The site now offers migration conditions for fish that are equal to or better than previous conditions.",,2024-10-03T19:58:37Z,9,692426,6032341,Yes,2,Yes,No,,7,0,0,No,3,5.5,2,Yes,No,Deep Fill,Medium,,,,,,,,,,,,newgraph_airvine,No,Yes,,,1,1,1,3,This is a brand-new pipe well-sized for the stream. Road runoff areas along the embankment are armored with rock for added stability.,1,4,4,7,"The brand-new, well-sized structure appears very unlikely to fail. While high-value habitat may exist downstream, the low gradient would likely dissipate energy in the unlikely event of structural failure.",10,10,1,1,10,3,35,42,"This was an extremely complicated and expensive construction project, reportedly taking two years to complete with likely very high costs. It is located on the main highway, crossing what is essentially the main stem of the Upper Bulkley River.",ignore_mobile/photos/20241003_131507.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241003_131518.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241003_131530.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241003_131525.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241003_131510.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241003_131528.jpg,,ignore_mobile/photos/20241003_131538.jpg,,,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

column1: 2024-09-20T22:23:00Z,58264,,LS TP,,newgraph_lschick,58264,newgraph_lschick,,,,370,Simpson Creek,Nielson Road,,MoTi,Closed Bottom Structure,Oval Culvert,,2.4,23,"This concrete oval culvert has a significant 1 m outlet drop, likely inhibiting fish passage. The stream is incorrectly mapped in the Freshwater Atlas, located south of the mapped channel. Upstream habitat includes boulder cover, gravel pockets suitable for coho, steelhead, and Dolly Varden spawning, and a healthy mature mixed forest riparian zone. Downstream habitat transitions to lower-gradient, high-value conditions with extensive gravels, deep pools (up to 90 cm), large woody debris, and abundant cover, supporting recent steelhead and historically chinook spawning, as reported by the adjacent landowner. Habitat confirmations were completed at this site and all downstream crossings to the confluence with Kathlyn Creek. The stream is a major contributor to the greater Kathlyn Creek watershed, with flow volumes during the assessment slightly less than the Kathlyn Creek mainstem. Electrofishing upstream of Nielsen Road captured rainbow trout, while downstream sampling confirmed the presence of Dolly Varden, rainbow trout, cutthroat trout/rainbow trout hybrids, and coho. The coho were captured approximately 350 m downstream of Nielsen Road. According to the landowner, this crossing was originally a bridge but was replaced with the current culvert during an emergency flood event in the 1990s.",,2024-09-20T22:23:00Z,9,614280,6074951,No,,,No,,0.4,1,1.2,No,5,5.6,13,No,Yes,Deep Fill,High,,,,,,,,,,,,,No,No,Yes,high,,,,,"Concrete oval culvert,  in good shape.",,,,,"The culvert is likely undersized for the stream, and a flood could potentially wash out Nielson Road, which provides access to several residences. Although the concrete culvert would require substantial force to fail, the stream is significant in size with only 0.4 m of road fill, increasing the risk.",,,,,,,,,"High-value spawning habitat downstream means construction could have significant environmental impacts. Although the road is low-traffic, it is paved, so construction would require substantial effort and likely disrupt access to residences. This crossing should be replaced with a bridge.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,TRUE,,TRUE
